e_subTitle: Select the best answer to each question before the timer runs out.
e_specialPrompts: You have one minute to answer each question. Throughout this game, you'll move forward by selecting the X to close my responses. Ready to get started? Close this box to begin.
That was the last question! Let's get some feedback on your results.
tryAgainPrompt: We will cover the questions you missed. Ready to get started?

introModal.e_title: It’s Time to Race Against the Clock!
introModal.e_text:
Let’s see how much you know about commercialization at 3M. In the following challenge, you’ll be presented with questions about key commercialization concepts. These questions will look familiar if you have completed the 3M | Grow Commercialization Introduction course.

Answer carefully, but also quickly. A timer will start counting down when each question appears. Once you’re out of time, you’ll have to move ahead to the next question.

Ready? Let’s go!

conclusionModal.e_text:
Now you've done: Quality with a Commercialization Challenge.

Time for the next part!

low.e_text:
It seems like your recollection of concepts related to commercialization at 3M could benefit from a refresher. If you wish, revisiting the 3M | Grow Commercialization course could be helpful.

Select Continue to complete this lesson. Or, if you’d like to improve your score, select Try Again.

med.e_title: You might want to review the questions you missed.
med.e_text:
It seems like your recollection of concepts related to commercialization at 3M could benefit from a refresher. If you wish, revisiting the 3M | Grow Commercialization Introduction course could be helpful.

Select Continue to complete this lesson. Or, if you’d like to improve your score, select Try Again. You'll be taken to the questions you missed.

high.e_text: You did fantastic! It looks like you’re pretty familiar with commercialization at 3M. Select Continue to complete this lesson. Or, if you’d like an opportunity to re-try a question if you missed one or two, select Try Again.

perfect.e_text: You did fantastic! It looks like you’re pretty familiar with commercialization at 3M. Select Continue to complete this lesson. Or, if you’d like an opportunity to re-try a question if you missed one or two, select Try Again.

questions.e_questionText:
Which term fits the following description:
“A process with target dates and financial components to bring new products, services, and solutions to market.”
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

choices.e_text: Value Stream
choices.e_feedback:
Not quite.

A value stream is the set of actions that take place to add value to a customer from the initial request through realization of value by the customer.

Close this prompt to advance to the next question.

choices.e_text: Commercialization
choices.e_feedback:
You got it!

Commercialization can be defined as a process that uses phases and gates to guide products, services, and solutions to market using a variety of components.

Close this prompt to advance to the next question.

choices.e_text: Go to Market Strategy
choices.e_feedback:
Not quite.

The Go to Market Strategy is a plan created in the Build a Business Case phase and identifies market size, trends, pricing and branding strategy, and future product expansion, among other items.

Close this prompt to advance to the next question.

questions.e_questionText: Why does 3M validate a product design with customers?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

prompts.e_text: What do you think? There's more than one answer here.

feedback.e_correct:
You’re on the right track!

Validation helps to ensure that the product design meets the customer’s needs in their process and that the product specifications are complete and predict performance.
feedback.e_incorrect:
You’re not quite there.

Validation helps to ensure the product design meets the customer’s needs and the product specifications are complete and predict performance.

choices.e_text: To ensure the product meets the customer needs
To ensure the product specification is complete and predictive of performance during customer use
To determine if additional products or services can be developed at the same time
To be compliant with the process

questions.e_questionText:
Which term matches this description:
“A workflow process used to develop and launch new products, consisting of phases, gate reviews, multifunctional deliverables, and financial plans.”
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question. Close this prompt to move on.

choices.e_text: 3M | Grow
choices.e_feedback:
That’s it!

3M | Grow is the gold standard process used for launching new products. 3M|Grow is designed with phases, deliverables, tasks, and gate reviews to manage risk and ensure quality.

choices.e_text: Global Launch Plan
choices.e_feedback:
Not exactly.

The Global Launch Plan helps demonstrate that there is a strategy to achieve a successful global product launch, consisting of activities such as the Launch Readiness There is a better answer.

choices.e_text: New Product Classification
choices.e_feedback:
Not exactly.

New Product Classification is a system which helps project teams and management clarify the rigor and support needed for a successful new product launch. There is a better answer.

questions.e_questionText: Which of the following are key deliverable categories of commercialization in 3M|Grow?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

feedback.e_correct:
You got it!

Commercialization at 3M can be organized into five key deliverables throughout each phase. Customer/Market and Business opportunity are two of the five key deliverables.
feedback.e_incorrect:
You’re not quite there.

Commercialization at 3M can be broken into 5 key deliverables throughout each phase. Customer/Market and Business opportunity are 2 of the 5 key deliverables.

choices.e_text: Customer/Market
Media exposure
Business opportunity
Competitive analysis

questions.e_questionText: Which of the following are functions of a gate review?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

prompts.e_text: Consider your choices here and choose more than one.

feedback.e_correct:
That’s it!

All of these are functions of gate reviews, which take place between the phases of 3M | Grow.
feedback.e_incorrect:
Not quite.

All of these are functions of gate reviews, which take place between the phases of 3M | Grow.

choices.e_text: Allowing stakeholders to review the status of the product and process
Confirming the product meets the deliverables for the phase and there is agreement to proceed to the next phase.
Obtaining sign-off on the product before it is fully commercialized

questions.e_questionText: What is the purpose of control plans?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

choices.e_text: Identifying which team members will step in to address issues with the process
choices.e_feedback:
Not really.

Managing process risk within a project or team is not the purpose of control plans.

choices.e_text: Ensuring the product will be able to compete with similar products to increase profits and market share
choices.e_feedback:
Not really.

This description would better describe competitive analysis, which is not directly related to control plans.

choices.e_text: Identifying appropriate action to ensure that the product is made right the first time
choices.e_feedback:
Yes!

Control plans are used to identify appropriate next steps if a product’s performance is out of range. This performance is determined using Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

questions.e_questionText: In Build Business Case of 3M | Grow, which questions should be answered?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

prompts.e_text: Think about this and choose more than one answer.

feedback.e_correct:
Awesome!

One of the primary purposes of Business Business Case is establishing that a new product is likely to be successful. To help fulfill this goal, all three of these questions are vital to answer.
feedback.e_incorrect:
You’re not quite there.

One of the primary purposes of the Business Case is establishing that a new product is likely to be successful. To help fulfill this goal, all three of these questions are vital to answer.

choices.e_text: Is the product or service feasible?
Can the product or service be manufactured or produced to meet customer requirements?
Is the product or service a good investment from a business success standpoint?

questions.e_questionText:
Which tool or deliverable best matches the following description:
“A method for connecting customer requirements to the final product and process validation.”
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

choices.e_text: Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
choices.e_feedback:
Not quite.

The FMEA identifies known or potential failure related to design, process, or usability and their respective mitigations. There is a better answer.

choices.e_text: Design Review
choices.e_feedback:
Close, but not quite.

The design review engages the cross-functional team to identify potential issues early. While customer requirements are a part of this, there is a better answer.

choices.e_text: Design Qualification Matrix (DQM)
choices.e_feedback:
Yes!

The DQM is a tool used to connect customer requirements to validation.

questions.e_questionText: Motivations, influences, and other end-user data are used to compile which of the following?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

choices.e_text: Customer Persona
choices.e_feedback:
You got it!

The customer persona consists of descriptions of the target customer or end-user, including their motivations, influences, and other metrics.

choices.e_text: Customer Buying Journey
choices.e_feedback:
Close, but not quite.

The customer buying journey is related to customer or end-user descriptions, but it is more concerned with their experiences with previous product purchases rather than data about the customer themselves.

choices.e_text: Value Proposition
choices.e_feedback:
Close, but not quite.

A product’s value proposition is a profile of its features and competitive advantage. This will be linked to a customer’s description, but it doesn’t describe the customer directly.

questions.e_questionText: Which of the following best describes why 3M commercialization teams complete a Project Wrap?
questions.e_timesUpMessage: Time’s up! Time to move onto the next question.

choices.e_text: Identifying what went wrong during the process
choices.e_feedback:
Close, but not quite.

While identifying what, if anything, went wrong during a project can be an important part of a project wrap, there is a better answer.

choices.e_text: Selecting who will participate on the next project
choices.e_feedback:
Not quite.

The project wrap is not necessarily used to identify immediate next projects or what team will complete them.

choices.e_text: Capturing best practices and key learnings while documenting the project outcome
choices.e_feedback:
That’s it!

The project wrap is completed after a product is launched to capture best practices, key learnings, and to document the process so continual improvement can happen.
